DOCNAME: GOUDSWAARD-VAN DER LANS v. THE NETHERLANDS
TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , is a GPE national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . She is represented before the Court by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government are represented by Mr R.A.A. PERSON , of ORG .

In the interest of the proper administration of justice , the President has granted leave to the following persons to submit written comments : PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON , PERSON PERSON , PERSON , PERSON and Mr PERSON ( Article CARDINAL of LAW CARDINAL § CARDINAL of ORG ) . These persons , referred to hereafter as “ third parties ” , are represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE .

The applicant ’s husband died on DATE . The applicant was left with CARDINAL children born in DATE and DATE respectively . She was granted a pension under the General Widows and Orphans Act ( Algemene Weduwen- en PERSON ; “ AWW ” ) .
She entered into a relationship with a Mr H. , by whom she had a child in DATE , and set up home with him some time before DATE .
At the time of the events complained of , the applicant ’s AWW pension amounted to MONEY ( NLG ) DATE .
The AWW was repealed on DATE and replaced by LAW ( PERSON ; “ ANW ” ) .

By a decision of DATE the competent executive authority , ORG ( ORG ) , reduced the applicant ’s pension to NLG MONEY DATE , with effect from DATE . The reason for this reduction was the fact that the applicant had been living with PERSON on DATE , the date on which the ORG entered into force , and was expected to continue to do so beyond DATE .
On DATE the applicant lodged an objection against this decision with ORG . It was dismissed on CARDINAL DATE .
On DATE the applicant lodged an appeal with ORG ( arrondissementsrechtbank ) .
On DATE , owing to the entry into force of new transitional legislation ( the Act of DATE see below ) , ORG raised the applicant ’s pension to ORG DATE , with effect from DATE .

On DATE the applicant ’s representative wrote to ORG informing it that the applicant ’s appeal was CARDINAL of several that had been selected as pilot cases intended to allow the courts to establish case - law . On DATE ORG also wrote to confirm this .

ORG gave a decision on DATE declaring the appeal well - founded on grounds not relevant to the case before the ORG . It quashed the decisions of DATE and DATE but left the effects of the latter decision unaffected .

On DATE the applicant lodged a further appeal with ORG ( ORG ) , the highest tribunal with jurisdiction in social - security matters . ORG also lodged an appeal , directed against aspects of ORG decision with which it disagreed .

ORG dismissed the applicant ’s further appeal in a decision delivered in open court on DATE and notified to the applicant on DATE . It accepted that there had been a “ partial deprivation of possessions ” within the meaning of LAW No . CARDINAL to the Convention . Its reasoning included the following :

“ In this legal provision [ i.e. section CARDINAL of the ANW – see below ] CARDINAL of the basic assumptions of the ORG , namely that statutory insurance for surviving dependants should be based on actual need ( dat aan een wettelijke nabestaandenverzekering het behoefteprincipe QUANTITY grondslag moet liggen ) , has been elaborated in respect of former recipients of AWW pensions . As compared to the ordinary ORG regime DATE under which , in short , the pension is reduced by the entire amount of work - related benefits [ i.e. unemployment and disability benefits ] and by income from work excluding a sum equal to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage before tax , plus CARDINAL of any income in excess thereof – the deduction applicable to former AWW beneficiaries under LAW of DATE – see below ] is more advantageous : PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage before tax , in respect of both forms of income , together with CARDINAL of any income from work in excess thereof , is disregarded for the purposes of the reduction . It can also be said in such cases that , regardless of the level of income , an amount of benefit equal to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage before tax remains unaffected .

As regards the transitional regime under LAW ANW it is also relevant that , in the case of persons maintaining a common household who are treated under the ORG as married persons ( with the exception of first - degree relatives ) , the former AWW beneficiary who is regarded as married on this ground retains , from DATE , an ORG pension equal to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage , that percentage in the case of persons maintaining a common household in order to take care of an invalid rising to PERCENT ( of the statutory minimum wage after tax ) , PERCENT of which is means - tested .
ORG held that this result was consistent with the criteria embodied in LAW No . CARDINAL , which provides :

ORG agrees that the transitional arrangements under the ORG fulfil those criteria , and in particular that the legislature , in determining what can and must be considered necessary in the general interest , has not overstepped its margin of appreciation . In addition to ORG findings on this point , ORG considers the following important : according to current opinion the statutory insurance regime for surviving dependants acts as a basic provision ( bodemvoorziening ) in terms of supplementary arrangements for surviving dependants and as an income provision ( inkomensvoorziening ) at the level of the social minimum . This does not sit well with the idea of leaving the ( basic ) benefit intact where circumstances indicate that the surviving dependant concerned is , or has been , able to meet his or her own needs . The fact that there was no provision of this nature in the AWW may plausibly be attributed to the then insignificant proportion of married women in employment , as a consequence of which the concurrence of an AWW pension and a salary , or social benefit in lieu of salary ( loondervingsuitkeringen ) , was relatively rare . From the perspective of the aims of the new system , the social changes in this area required an arrangement that dealt with the concurrence of benefits for surviving dependants and other income . In addition , the legislature found it appropriate to extend the equal treatment of married couples and unmarried cohabitants ( in a general sense ) , as for other social arrangements , to the statutory insurance for surviving dependants .

The fact that the adaptations in question also extend to existing cases ( persons in receipt of AWW pensions ) is considered acceptable by ORG within the scope of its present review , from the equality point of view , and also in the light of the potentially considerable duration of the benefit ; and what is also acceptable within the same scope of review is the position of the legislature that , in terms of legal security , a temporary and/or partial ( in the present case : an initially complete and subsequently partial ) respect for existing rights is required .

The position that only ‘ full compensation’ would be consistent with LAW No . CARDINAL , as has been argued by the persons concerned by the cases dealt with in the present proceedings , is based on an incorrect understanding of that provision , which does not go so far as to make it utterly impossible for a ORG to make changes to existing ( social security ) rights . ”

The AWW , which entered into force on DATE , insured against the risk of the death of the family breadwinner . Under the AWW scheme , all persons residing in the GPE and non - residents gainfully employed in the GPE were compulsorily insured . Contributions to this scheme were paid by all persons gainfully employed in the GPE .

Entitlement to AWW benefit was not dependent on the level of contributions paid as , unlike a social - security scheme based on employment ( werknemersverzekering ) , it was a nationwide social - security scheme ( volksverzekering ) . The level of benefit was linked to the statutory minimum wage .

The AWW conferred entitlement to a widow ’s pension on the widow of an insured person , provided she was under DATE and was caring for an unmarried child born or conceived no later than the date of her spouse ’s death . A widow without children was also entitled to claim benefit subject to certain conditions , for example if she was incapacitated for work or was aged DATE or over at the time of her husband ’s death . “ Widow ” meant the woman to whom the insured person was married on the date of his death .

At the time when the AWW was replaced by the ORG , the amount of the pension was equal to the statutory minimum wage after tax in the case of a widow with dependent children below the age of DATE , and PERCENT of that wage in other cases . This amount was the same for all widows , regardless of any income which they might have been receiving from other sources .
Entitlement to an AWW pension was lost upon remarriage .
DATE , widowers enjoyed the same entitlement to benefit after the death of their wives pursuant to the case - law of the domestic tribunals under LAW .

By DATE the Government of the day felt that the AWW , based as it was on the traditional division of labour between men and women , had become obsolete . It gave surviving dependants an entitlement to benefit even if they were not in need of it : increasingly , beneficiaries included widows and widowers in paid employment .

For this reason the Government decided to introduce new legislation granting an entitlement to a pension only to certain categories of surviving dependants who could not be expected either to provide entirely for themselves or to take out private insurance .
A first bill was introduced in DATE . It was rejected by ORG of ORG , which disapproved of , among other things , the proposed transitional provisions .
A revised bill was introduced during ORG ’s DATE - CARDINAL session .

CARDINAL , CARDINAL , DATE session , no . CARDINAL ) .
The ANW ( Act of DATE , ORG ) DATE , no . CARDINAL , as amended ( with retroactive effect from DATE ) by LAW DATE , ORG , no . CARDINAL ) entered into force on DATE .

Under LAW of the ORG , the persons insured under LAW are those who are either GPE residents or , if not GPE residents , are liable for wage tax ( loonbelasting ) in respect of work carried out in the GPE under a contract of employment .

Section CARDINAL of the ORG provides that the surviving dependants of an insured person shall be entitled to a pension if they have an unmarried child under DATE who does not form part of any other person ’s household , or if they are unfit for work , or if they were born before DATE .

Section CARDINAL provides for the termination of the entitlement to an ANW pension in the event that the surviving dependant no longer meets the requirements of section DATE ( unless he or she was born before DATE ) or reaches DATE ( at which age , in the GPE , one normally becomes entitled ipso facto to an old - age pension under different legislation ) .

The ANW pension is equal , after tax , to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage after tax ( section CARDINAL ) . The pension is reduced by an amount equal to the surviving dependant ’s other income , if any ; however , a proportion of income from paid employment ( inkomen uit arbeid ) equal to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage before tax plus , if the surviving dependant ’s income from work exceeds that sum , CARDINAL of the remainder , is disregarded for the purposes of the deduction ( section CARDINAL ) .
Section CARDINAL laid down a transitional regime for persons who , before the entry into force of the ORG , had been entitled to benefit under the AWW .

In accordance with CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) , persons , like the applicant who maintained a common household with another person on DATE on which the ORG entered into force ( i.e. DATE ) , and were still maintaining that common household on DATE , lost their entitlement to an ANW pension entirely with effect from DATE unless they were born before DATE , in which case they were entitled to an ANW pension amounting to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage ( after tax ) .

As originally enacted in DATE , the ORG provided that persons previously entitled to an AWW pension who maintained a common household with another person on DATE on which the ORG entered into force lost their entitlement to an ANW pension entirely with effect from DATE unless they were born before DATE , in which case they were entitled to an ANW pension amounting to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage ( after tax ) .

The Act of DATE amending the transitional regime and introducing certain technical adaptations ( PERSON tot wijziging PERSON nabestaandenwet ( wijziging overgangsrecht alsmede QUANTITY technische aanpassingen ) ) amended this arrangement , limiting it to those who were still maintaining a common household with someone else on DATE ( CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the ANW – see above ) .

As early as CARDINAL DATE the Deputy Minister for ORG and Employment ( Staatssecretaris van Sociale Zaken en GPE ) decided on a “ Temporary ORG of the ANW ” ( PERSON regeling reparaties overgangswet ANW ; Official Bulletin ( Staatscourant ) DATE , no . CARDINAL , page CARDINAL ) . Its stated intention was to remove some of the effects of CARDINAL of the ORG , which were widely felt to be excessively harsh in that they frequently led to the complete termination of entitlement to an ANW pension .

The solution chosen , as relevant to the present case , was to reduce the ANW pension of surviving dependants who had previously enjoyed an AWW pension and were cohabiting in a common household to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage ( after tax ) regardless of their date of birth .
This temporary arrangement was withdrawn with effect from DATE ( Official Bulletin CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL , page CARDINAL) , having been made redundant by the LAW of DATE ( see below ) .

The LAW of DATE amending the ORG in view of apparent unfairness ( PERSON DATE tot wijziging PERSON nabestaandenwet in verband met gebleken onbillijkheden ; Official Gazette DATE , no . CARDINAL ) , amended section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the ORG to provide , in so far as relevant to the case before the ORG , that for persons previously entitled to an AWW pension who maintained a common household with someone else on DATE , for reasons other than taking care of an invalid , and who were still maintaining that household on DATE , the ORG pension would be reduced to PERCENT of the statutory minimum wage ( before tax ) with effect from DATE .
